Bottom-Up and Top-down Controls

Arrows indicate that a change in biomass affects another trophic level. There are three general levels: v ‚û°Ô∏è h (increase in vegetation increases herbivore biomass), h ‚û°Ô∏è v (increase in herbivore biomass will decrease the abundance of vegetation), h üîÅ v (both of the species affect each other)

Bottom-Up Model (v ‚û°Ô∏è h)

The simple form is n ‚û°Ô∏è v ‚û°Ô∏è h ‚û°Ô∏è p

Where n is nutrients, v is vegetation, h is herbivores, and p is predators. Thus, to change the make up of this ecosystem you have to add more nutrients to the soil which increases the number of all above tiers.

Top-Down Model (v ‚¨ÖÔ∏è h)

The simple form is n ‚¨ÖÔ∏è v ‚¨ÖÔ∏è h ‚¨ÖÔ∏è p

If p is reduce, h is increased which reduces v, which increases n. This creates an alternating effect of increase and decreases.
